newsitem.title: INDIA: India insurers want checks on foreign access.
newsitem.headline: India insurers want checks on foreign access.

text.p: Indian insurance industry leaders said on Thursday they wanted an end to a state monopoly, but not free access for foreign firms.

A day after the government buckled under opposition pressure and hastily withdrew a bill aimed at setting up an insurance regulator, businessmen said foreign firms must be restricted to minority shareholdings in private joint ventures.

"The insurance sector needs urgent liberalisation, but there is no doubt in my mind that Indian firms should have a majority stake in insurance joint ventures," N. Kumar, president of the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), told reporters.

Speaking on the sidelines of an international conference on insurance, Kumar said the CII backed the recommendations of a committee that wanted foreign investors in the business, but sought extra safeguards for Indian firms.
The Malhotra committee, set up in 1993, had said that private entrepreneurs starting joint ventures should hold 40 percent and sell off 60 percent of equity to the public.
Kumar said Indian firms must hold a majority within the 40 percent of total equity held together with foreign partners.
Shambu Anand, general manager, insurance services at J.K. Corp Ltd, said: "It is very necessary to protect Indian interests. Foreigners must remain within specified parameters."

Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral withdrew an insurance regulatory bill from the lower house of parliament on Wednesday, after his coalition failed to muster enough votes to defeat an opposition-backed amendment barring the entry of foreign firms.
Gujral said on Wednesday that the government would reintroduce the Insurance Regulatory Authority of India Bill after consultations with various political parties.
The bill was seen as an initial step to pave the way for foreign companies' entry into the huge and potentially lucrative sector.
In 1996, Indians paid 130 billion rupees ($3.64 billion) as life insurance premiums and 69 billion rupees ($1.93 billion) as general insurance premiums to state monopolies.
The Finance Ministry estimates annual growth rates in both businesses to be between 15 and 20 percent.
Anand said if there were no limits on foreign equity in a joint venture, the Indian partner might want to sell out to foreign partners within two or three years.
India nationalised its life insurance business in 1957, when 245 companies were merged to form the state-owned Life Insurance Corporation of India.
In 1973, 107 companies were nationalised under the umbrella of the General Insurance Corporation (GIC), which covered all areas of insurance except life cover.
Anand said India's private firms had been out of the general insurance business for only 20 years and retained the required expertise to run the business.
"We need nothing more than some of the systems and the products that foreign companies have."

Before nationalisation, India's front-ranking business families controlled leading insurance companies. The Tatas owned New India Assurance, the Birlas ran Ruby Insurance, and the Singhanias owned National Insurance Co.
